newsitem.title: JAPAN: Two Japanese mobile phone firms discuss tie-up.
newsitem.headline: Two Japanese mobile phone firms discuss tie-up.

text.p: Japanese long-distance carrier DDI Corp said on Monday that its mobile phone affiliate, the Cellular Telephone Co group, is in talks with Nippon Idou Tsushin Corp on jointly introducing the CDMA standard for next-generation digital cellular phone services.

The DDI spokesman said, however, that the two companies had not agreed on building a common nationwide network, providing common services and sharing equipment as reported by a Japanese business daily on Monday.

The Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported that the Cellular Telephone group, Japan's second largest mobile phone operator, will tie up with Nippon Idou Tsushin, the industry's fifth largest, in next-generation digital cellular phone services to be launched in 1998.
The Cellular Telephone group, which is comprised of eight firms, has 3.3 million subscribers, while Nippon Idou, an affiliate of Toyota Motor Corp, has 1.7 million, the paper said.
CDMA (Cord division multiple access) is a digital phone standard used in the United States as opposed to the GMS standard applied in Europe. CDMA allows more efficient use of radio frequencies.
